Of course, it didn't help that Dudley Do-Right cartoons were invariably shorts, rather ones that beget complicated situations.The cartoon had the premise of a strong and handsome but dense hero doing battle against the villain Snidely Whiplash, succeeding in the end when he finally uses his head. (One episode has him fooling Snidely into thinking some dynamite exploded when it didn't because he tricked him using a recording of an explosion-but Dudley had failed to defuse the real dynamite.) So what happens here? Snidely starts a fake gold rush, and Dudley eventually foils his plans. This could have been the basis of something good, but a confusing and unfunny story, ethnic stereotypes, and performers who don't correspond very well to their cartoon equivalents make this a bad movie. Even Dudley Do-Right completists should stay away.

reviews.review_title: Likable actors, but not goofy enough to work as a cartoon remake
reviews.content: The movie is earnest, and fairly well done from a technical standpoint, but it falls short of the intense goofiness of the original TV cartoons. Placed as a recurring feature within the weekly cartoon series, The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show, the original Dudley Do-Right cartoons relied mostly on a few running gags: Dudley's unimpeachable honesty and allegiance to 19th century Canadian Mountie ideals, as well as his innocent love and preference for his faithful horse over his erstwhile girlfriend Nell. Snidely Whiplash's angst and concern over his role as a villain, and how he continually monitors his behavior to gauge his success at being evil was absurd and amusing. The James Mason-ish Inspector Fenwick, who maintained the same oily yet dry British upper class drawl whether he was giving orders to Dudley to counter Snidely's latest attempt to take over Canada, congratulating Dudley on a job well done, or stripping Dudley of his rank because he fell victim to one of Whiplash's set-ups or hoaxes was also great. It was all done in broad strokes, as caricatures of the social roles defining law and order, criminality, authority, the media itself, and gender. It was funny, it was sly, and at about three minutes per week it was just enough.The movie, on the other hand, falls short in the cartoonishness necessary to make the Dudley Do-Right elements entertaining. Dudley was underplayed by the otherwise brilliant Brandon Fraser. He came across as likable and honest, but was too close to reality to be particularly funny. Nell seemed more flaky than romantically frustrated, as the cartoon had her. Maybe that was a bow to modern feminism, but it deprived the character of the contrast and drama that used to be funny. What was left, and now visible on the screen, was just "a blond lady." Nell's father, Inspector Fenwick, was so blank as to be a non-character. That James Mason-ish hold-the-empire-together, and close-your-eyes-and-think-of-Britain droll absurdity from the original cartoon would have been easy enough to bring to the movie screen, but this movie didn't even try. Remakes and re-enactments don't need to be models of exactitude, of course. But if not a reprint of the original, a remake does need to conjure up a similar vibe.Fraser's other Jay Ward movie re-enactment, George Of the Jungle, was a much better job. It worked both as a movie itself, and as a faithful re-do of Ward's original. It evoked the TV cartoon series, thus satisfying nostalgia and all of that for the fans, yet it also did what movies need to do to grab and entertain the actual folks currently sitting in the theater. Dudley Do-Right missed this. During the showing I attended, I think I chuckled twice and laughed twice, each time hearing a handful of adult voices with mine. A couple of times I heard children's small little voices laughing-- each when someone got hit in the head and fell down. This wasn't enough. It needed to be much more of a movie to watch and enjoy independently of any remake or nostalgia vibe. George of the Jungle was a movie first, and a remake second. Dudley Do-Right was, on the whole, pretty much just a remake, and not a great one at that. I gave it a 6, even though I was really hoping it could have been much more.

reviews.review_title: Dudley Do-Wrong in this awful comedy
reviews.content: I have a feeling that every few years there needs to be a movie like "Spy Hard" and "Inspector Gadget"; however, it needs to have really funny jokes; Dudley Do-Right didn't. Brendan Fraser really wasted his time and talent in a movie that clearly had no plot or humor. The only thing that possibly stood out in my mind as being good was the narrator because he is the one who kept it interesting for me.

"It's the script, stupid!"  So should the producers of this bomb have been reminded before allowing a single camera to roll.  Basic premise: the audience must empathise with the hero or heroine.  We didn't--nothing compelled us to do so.  The characters were so poorly developed that empathy was unlikely, at best.While the cast is superb, their performances are anything but:  to a person, each looked embarrassed to participate in this ill-conceived outing. Characterization?  Forget it.  The director makes no attempt to capture the essence of the cartoon.  Where is Dudley's nasal-tenor voice?  The inspector's high-tone speech pattern?  Nell's ramrod-straight bearing? Snidely's CHIN, for Pete's sake???  (Molina's Snidely is the one almost-OK performance here.  Pity that the addition of a moustache isn't enough to transform the moon-faced Molina into the Snidely we hoped to see.)Skip this one, folks.  It won't be hard to do: chances are that its theatrical life will be short indeed.

I have to admit that when this movie first came out I groaned, "Oh, no! Not another TV show going movie" But I was pleasantly surprised at the way this turned out.  The cartoons were cute enough, the movie is just plain fun, quite enjoyable.  Snidely's band of evil-doers particularly amusing, as were the Kumquat tribe.  Great tongue in cheek humor sprinkled throughout.A movie you can safely sit back with the popcorn and enjoy with your kids and grandkids.

I feel somewhat pity for Jay Ward, the cartoon genius who essentially created the tongue-in-cheek joke for kids.  He has missed out on the fruits of his work turning into great live-action movies.Upon entering the theater, I felt hesitant.  The trailers seemed to show only a broad slap-stick side to Dudley (getting hit on the head one too many times).  If the movie was unable to recapture the silly mood of it's predesessor, it would be a total failure.  Call me a skeptic if you wish, but I was expecting the worst.  Thankfully, I was wrong.  Dudley was a fine ol' comedy that is great for adults but perfect for kids.In case you don't know, Dudley Do-Right was a cartoon created by Jay Ward. Dudley was a idiot Canadian Mountie who was always rescuing his beloved Nell from the evil Snidely Whiplash.  He's tie her to the railroad tracks, he's someone end up saving her.  But in the process, Dudley's antics (along with a sarcastic narrator) left you rolling in stitches.The movie tells the tale of Dudley (Brendan Fraser)and his evil counterpart Snidley (Alfred Molina). Snidley has been planting gold in "them thar hills" of Semi-Happy Valley in Canada.  When a prospector by the name of Kim Darling (Eric Idle) finds this gold, it turns into the biggest gold rush ever, turns Semi-Happy Valley into Whiplash City, and do to a mistaken case of vampires and government conspiracy (thanks to Snidley), leaves our hero kicked out of the Mounties!  And to top it all off for poor Dudley, Nell Fenwick (Sarah Jessica Parker) has fallen for Snidley and Horse, his horse (played by McFly, no lie), has run off!!!  So Dudley must become bad to out bad Snidley's bad which has turned the delapitated town into a thriving community which is good.  Confused?  Well, it's not that tough."Dudley Do-Right", while overall very similar to the cartoon, is also very different.  The saddest part to me is that Dudley had the voice of Brendan Fraser and not something closer to his original tone, which is a shame because Fraser did the voice on "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart" and he was perfect.  Another difference is that while Nell was helpless and in love with Dudley in the cartoon, in the movie she seems to love Snidley more often and in a woman of the world.  This added part to her character makes us not like the character at all.  "If Dudley doesn't get the girl, lucky him!"Now on to the good parts of the movie.  The plot zips by at a frantic speed, slowing down for all the good parts. You get just enough of the story to know what's going on and then onto the jokes.  And laughs there are a plenty.  While there is plenty of that aformentioned slapstick, it thankfully is gone after the first 20 minutes.  Once you get to the Indian Dance number, you're home free.One of the better gags in the movie involves the indian tribe of the Kumquat nation (all of them apparrently straight from New York).  The Chief (Alex Rocco) owns a dinner theater complete with a musical extravaganza and fireworks.  If you thought the native american shows you've seen were kind of hokey, wait till you see the Kumquat nation "Riverdance".  Another good riff is when the prospector receives his fifteen minutes of fame...on Live with Regis and Kathy Lee (yes, you get to see his appearance).  Once he becomes a bum again, he goes around uttering "I was on Regis and Kathy Lee" and "I know Bette Midler personally" (no, you don't get to see her appearance).But Kim Darling, the prospector isn't just there for a joke or two.  When Dudley becomes fired, Kim takes Dudley under his wing and turns him into a great hero following three steps "We'll start with two, for the sake of consistency: 2. trust, 1. bravery, and 3. instinct."  The training may be the oddest thing ever and remember, this is Eric Idle of Monty Python fame, so somehow, it seems even funnier with him in it.Of course, the best gag is shown in the trailer, but I'll mention it anyway. Dudley, in his first bad doing, steals Snidley's gold he's going to place. Then he leaves a little message for him ala Dick Tracy with a machine gun. He leaves his initials "D.D.".  Snidley, in a fit of anger, yells "Do you have any idea what this could possibly mean?"  The replies include Doris Day, Dom Deluise, Daniel Day Lewis, Snoop Doggy Dogg, David Duchovney and another name, which I won't tell to ruin the punchline.One odd little note is that Fraser did "The Mummy" before "Dudley Do-Right" and it seems to show.  In several occasions, he jumps into action star mode (one that suits him well).  Especially during a strangely thrilling motorcycle race that is very reminicent of "Return of the Jedi"'s swoop bike scene but only with a bit more humor.  The action is very intense for a kid flick and it's choice of music to get you in the mood(not during the scene), "Born to be Wild" on classic instruments, seems to work.(A quick message here.  Right before the movie is a cartoon of "Fractured Fairytales".  This cartoon, entitlted "The Phox, The Box, and The Lox" was so enjoyable, it makes you wonder why Universal doesn't start making more new cartoons for it's movies.  Or how about bringing them back to a TV show?)As for the ending of the movie, it leaves you feeling content yet yearning for more.  You can't help but wish there had been more or maybe something during the credits.  Do you hear that Universal, when "The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle" comes out, there better be gags in the credits!  As for "Dudley Do-Right", it may not be "George of the Jungle", but it's so close you could swear you see him.  And yes, before you start E-mailing me about it, I know.

One of the suckiest films I've seen!!!I should say that I couldn't take any more after about 15 mins so I turned it off. I don't think even kids will find it funny. It really underestimates the intelligence of ALL viewers! It's almost an insult from the filmmakers!

reviews.review_title: Loved George of the Jungle hated this...a word to the wise
reviews.content: I have been a life long fan of Jay Wards irreverent and hilarious cartoon characters. Dudley Do Right is one of his best.  After enjoying George of the Jungle I looked forward to this sort of "sequel".Dudley most recent incarnation is a major disappointment. It is silly but not funny. The dialogue and gags are heavy handed and miss Ward's light yet biting, wilding imaginative spoof of cultural stereotypes. Don't waste your time with this one..

If this movie was made to intentionally be as dumb, silly and stupid as possible, then I give full props to them. They did a great job. However, if this was a legit attempt at a movie (of which turns out to be based off of a TV cartoon show or something?) then they failed badly. I almost wished they were intentionally trying to be bad.It comes to the point where sometimes you want the bad guy to win just because the good guy isn't good enough, the script is terrible, or whatever the case may be. In this case, the pure fact that the gags in the movie were so dumb makes me wonder.I was rather impressed with a few gags here and there, and yes some of the jokes were rather funny, however all in all I just think it was rather dumb. At least there were no musicals... eck that would be been horrible! :PRated 4/10.

To the nay-sayers, critics and otherwise, this might not be for you, but I smiled all the way through it. I also liked the actors, Brendan Fraser (who again gets his role just right), Alfred Molina (great as the bad guy), Sarah Jessica Parker (good, but not quite enough to do in this one), Eric Idle (just right, as usual), the Indians (!!!) and Horse.  To all who brought this together, good job!

I went to this film to beat a hot Brisbane summer, and was pleasantly surprised.  Brendan Fraser is, of course, a hunk, and I drooled through most of the film.  I thought however, that the movie lacked that special something until Eric Idle came on the scene, and then it was superb.  I laughed myself silly, and enjoyed the little Riverdance, Karate Kid and a few other take offs.  The only problem with watching a kids movie is having to put up with the kids in the cinema.

My two young children didn't even like this film. Save your time and money. I thought it would be worth a try since my kids enjoyed "George of the Jungle" to the point that we later bought the video. This piece of disjointed garbage was obviously an attempt to follow up on the relative success of that film--but it fails miserably. The jokes were simply not funny and the script gave the impression that they were making this thing up as they went along. The slapstick didn't work at all and whoever played Whiplash, should be given at least 30 lashes-- just a terrible performance. Eric Idle tried to add just a little comedy to it, but even he couldn't save this dud.

An odd choice for a live-action adaptation, Dudley Do-Right is clearly trying to recapture what worked in the George of the Jungle movie but, aside from a scene-stealing Alfred Molina and a cartoon preceding the movie that's much funnier, its humour trying too hard to appeal to both audiences, unfocused plot and the jokes falling flat most of the time - the very short runtime doesn't help - shows that not every cartoon that had 15 minutes of fame needs to turn their protagonists into real boys and girls (or alternatively, glorified cosplay)...Molina does give it some "so bad, it's good" entertainment value.
Dudley Did-Wrong. This movie sucked big time.

There had been a fad in Hollywood decades ago for making live-action versions of old television cartoons. None really worked, but this one has done more badly than the others. Of course, it didn't help that Dudley Do-Right cartoons were invariably shorts, rather ones that beget complicated situations.

The cartoon had the premise of a strong and handsome but dense hero doing battle against the villain Snidely Whiplash, succeeding in the end when he finally uses his head. (One episode has him fooling Snidely into thinking some dynamite exploded when it didn't because he tricked him using a recording of an explosion-but Dudley had failed to defuse the real dynamite.) So what happens here? Snidely starts a fake gold rush, and Dudley eventually foils his plans. This could have been the basis of something good, but a confusing and unfunny story, ethnic stereotypes, and performers who don't correspond very well to their cartoon equivalents make this a bad movie. Even Dudley Do-Right completists should stay away.
One of my favorite childhood movies! Loved Brendan Fraser in this.

My blog with hot videos
https://tinyurl.com/mypersonalyblog

What the heck? SMH. If you don't like a character write a column about how you don't like the character. Don't write a full length movie that displays your loathing of said character. They should give a prize to anyone who can get through 20 minutes of this garbage.
Fraser is a great pick but the script is hit or miss.
could be one of the worst movie ever made.
What a wonderful, fun for the whole family movie. Comedy at every turn. Absolute classic.

Brendan Fraser has a career with odd choices and this film is a prime example. The silly child like humour appears to be aiming for the George of the Jungle crowd but the storyline is a gigantic mess. The film was a huge box office bomb and it's easy to see why, my first question is how the hell did they spend 70 million on this film? At no stage can you see the value on the screen, it looks like everybody loaded their pockets and phoned it in. The narration is utterly useless and uninspiring, why they kept this is beyond me. I liked this when I was a kid, but it's not good. The characters (save for Snidely Whiplash) are out of character, the plot is routine, the romance was cliche, and it wasn't sure it was trying to be a funny or serious movie when the cartoon was a parody of melodramas of the early 20th century. While it does have a few funny jokes like Snidely Whiplash convinces Dudley he was hunting for vampires as an excuse for shooting golden bullets in an abandon mine shaft to make money off of prospectors, most of the jokes and gags don't really work as most of it is either outdated slapstick, fart humor, and a reference to Pokemon (you hear right, a Pokemon reference).

Dudley Do-Right is an absurd comedy with moments of chuckles though there is the questionable satire that involves natives being played by non-natives.  

The film introduces the three main characters from childhood then at adulthood.  Dudley is a goofy, sincere, clumsy Mountie - fulfilling his childhood's destiny. 

 He has a friend named Nell whom he comes to love even though she takes up with his enemy (formerly his childhood friend).  The evil friend succeeds in his schemes until Dudley is fired as a Mountie and forced to beat his foe at his own games (Dudley meets a man who mentors him - in the tradition of Karate Kid and similar films).  The Mounties come to his aid and the natives as they are attacked by the enemy and his gang.  Sarah Jessica Parker is surprising at times, even appealing, as Nell.  6/10
A promising opening 10 minutes and a somewhat self-aware approach can't elevate this run-of-the-mill cartoon adaptation beyond the mediocrity of its many peers.

Brendan Fraser is a living cartoon character. In every film I've seen him in, he has zany characteristics and gives cheesy smiles at the camera. Even in "The Mummy", I feel like I'm watching an action-packed cartoon series. Universal tried to cash in on the success of Disney's "George of the Jungle" adaption with Brendan Fraser by putting him in a theatrical adaption of another Jay Ward (creator of "George of the Jungle") toon, "Dudley Do-Right".

The film felt like a quest to find a plot! The film is about a clumsy mountie named Dudley Do-Right (because he's always doing right!) who must stop his long time nemesis, Snidley Whiplash, from taking over Semi-Happy Valley. The rest is just a whole bunch of plot threads who were abused by hardly being developed.

Fraser is doing what he does best: acting weirdly. So I consider him to be the best actor in the film. Alfred Molina speaks in a annoying cartoonish voice. It worked sometimes at got out of hand for the remainder. Sarah Jessica Parker was acting terribly. She looked like the thought, "I'm getting paid for this, right?", ran through her head throughout her screen time. Supporting cast: LAME! Not even Eric Idle helped.

The humor is so flat! Eric Idle was not funny and so was Alfred Molina. Not even the "Pokemon" reference helped! When I did find something amusing, I replied with dry chcukles. I just wonder how much they paid the writer, Hugh Wilson. The other stupid thing was the opening credits. The titles, "Written by Hugh Wilson" and "Directed by Hugh Wilson", are seperate. Were they just too lazy to put "Written for the screen and directed by Hugh Wilson"? Laziness, people! Laziness! The film was even unsure of itself. It felt and anachronistic and bored of itself. The film was just lazy. It was flat, lazy, and supplied very little to children. Low on slapstick. What a shame. "Dudley Do-Right" is a do-wrong. The "George of the Jungle" movie was more butch and that live-action "Flintstones" movie had more dignity than this. Come on, Hollywood! Come on!

I was curious, but did not expect it to be very good. I am no longer curious and it was not very good. Fraser and Molina do an admirable job hamming it up, but there just isn't a lot here. I think I liked the cartoon, but it's been a while.

There are a couple of fun war parodies, but the only time I laughed out loud was at a news reporter on TV. "And this just in: scientists discover that Canadian Bacon is actually ordinary ham."

This is essentially a one joke movie. A few good slapstick scenes from Fraser (although they become very repetitive) cannot save this from being a poor movie. Alfred Molina's performance was dismal and he is far better suited to serious roles.

Similarly to the following year's Rocky and Bullwinkle movie, its dated humour is in tune with the original cartoon's and it does make an attempt to make some sort of meta in joke to the show rather than just rebooting it, yet it still flops, with nothing memorable or funny.

rt_summary: Based on the cartoon, this live-action comedy follows the adventures of Dudley Do-Right (Brendan Fraser), an enthusiastic, if somewhat dim, Canadian Mountie. When Dudley's childhood crush, Nell Fenwick (Sarah Jessica Parker), returns to their hometown in the mountains, he is eager to spend time with her, but his attempts at courting her are foiled by the villainous Snidely Whiplash (Alfred Molina), who is up to his usual schemes. Can Dudley win Nell's heart and curtail Snidely's wicked ways?
